title: Designing Mathematics Concept Teaching Materials Using Cognitive Load Theory and Multimedia Learning: Optimization of Formulas, Equations, and Graphs

context.prior_knowledge: Understanding of basic mathematical concepts (equations, functions, geometry), ability to interpret statistical charts, experience using online learning tools (digital whiteboards, video editors)
context.additional_context: Structured around math problem-solving cases linked to real-world tasks (engineering design, data analysis) to strengthen workplace relevance for in-service practitioners. It utilizes real-time interaction (digital whiteboard collaboration) and multimedia materials (video lectures, animated proof processes).

learning_goals: Learners can optimize the visual hierarchy of mathematical formulas and the step-by-step solving methods of equations by applying cognitive load theory.

According to dual coding theory, learners can design math concept explanation materials combining three types of graphs/figures (function graphs, geometric shapes, statistical charts) and two types of audio explanations (concept explanations, problem-solving solutions) and achieve an "excellent" rating in two or more of the three peer evaluation rubric items (clarity, integration, effectiveness).

Learners can develop customized math problem-solving instructional materials (step-by-step hints, proof process visualization) considering prior knowledge levels (basic operations, algebra, geometry) and motivation (problem-solving, concept exploration).
difficulty: Moderate - Standard complexity with some constraints
